content: Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization is addressed in Section 1. Taiwan's substantial achievements in health include high life expectancy and low maternal and infant mortality rates, making it important for international health cooperation. Taiwan has made significant strides in public health, comparable to western countries, by eradicating infectious diseases like cholera, smallpox, the plague, and polio, and providing hepatitis B vaccinations to children. The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention collaborates closely with Taiwan on various public health issues. Taiwan has also shown willingness to support international aid and health activities endorsed by the WHO. In response to an earthquake in El Salvador, Taiwan sent rescue teams and donated relief aid. The World Health Assembly allows observers to participate in its activities. The World Health Assembly allows observers to participate in its activities, including the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Order of Malta, and the Holy See. The United States supports Taiwan's participation in international organizations like the WHO. Taiwan should have meaningful participation in the WHO for the benefit of its people and global health. President Bush expressed the need for Taiwan's voice to be heard internationally. The US supports Taiwan's efforts to gain observership status at the World Health Assembly to benefit its people and global health. Taiwan has donated resources to control the spread of HIV/AIDS in response to appeals from the UN and the US. In December 2002, the US donated $1,000,000 to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. In 2003, Taiwan experienced 84 deaths due to the outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). The reemergence of avian influenza in Asia highlights the importance of global cooperation in disease control. The Secretary of Health and Human Services emphasized the need for all countries, including Taiwan, to have access to international health organizations like the WHO. The Secretary of State is authorized to endorse and obtain observer status for Taiwan at the World Health Assembly in Geneva. A report must be submitted to Congress describing the plan annually. The Secretary of State is authorized to endorse and obtain observer status for Taiwan at the World Health Assembly in Geneva. A report must be submitted to Congress annually detailing efforts to promote Taiwan's bid for observer status at the WHO. The House of Representatives passed a bill on April 21, 2004.
